div.p: Your kind letter has given us so much pleasure; I say us,, because I sent it on to Countess Pasolini. Her answer, in very pretty + quaint English, may interest you. And by her desire I am sending you a set of her catalogues, in case you ever see a chance of putting them in the hands of people to whom they may be of use. Is it a mere illusion of distance which makes me imagine you surrounded by people interested in the same things as yourself; or does one generously think that others must have whatever one feels the lack of? For my life abroad, in the country + among foreigners – a life which is now an unbreakable habit – prevents my coming in contact with such questions as interest you save through the means of books. And yet, sadly enough, questions of sociology + psychology are what interests me most; aesthetics (which is, so far as I have any ) my little bit of science) being for me essentially psychological + sociological.

You can believe how very pleased I shall be to have a chance of talking over such matters with you, + how warmly I thank you + Mrs Wells for your invitation. I shall let you know when I come to England in July.

Have you seen, I wonder, a sort of little French Anticipation, by my young semi socialist friend Daniel Halévy, called “Histoire de Quatre Ans” – which appeared in the Cahiers de la Quinzaine last autumn. I feel sure it would interest you, + its author would do so also. I shall ask him to send it you + I shall send him Anticipation, which I have given to several of my friends over here.
div.closer: Thanking you + hoping ere long to have the pleasure of better acquaintance, I am, dear Mr Wells,Yrs Truly V. Paget ("Vernon Lee")
